chapter.title: Data Structures
chapter.para: Python is having a few built-in data structure. If you are still wondering what is a data structure, then it is nothing a but a way to store data and the having particular methods to retrieve or manipulate it. We already saw lists before, now we will go in depth.

The easiest example can be of couple of marbles in an one side closed pipe. So if you want to take the marbles out of it you have to do that from the end where you entered the last marble. section.title: Tuples
section.para: Tuples are data separated by comma.
section.programlisting: >>> a = 'Fedora', 'Debian', 'Kubuntu', 'Pardus' >>> a ('Fedora', 'Debian', 'Kubuntu', 'Pardus') >>> a[1] 'Debian' >>> for x in a: ... print x, ... Fedora Debian Kubuntu Pardus
section.para: You can also unpack values of any tuple in to variables, like
Tuples are immutable, that means you can not del/add/edit any value inside the tuple. Here is another example
section.programlisting: >>> a = (1, 2, 3, 4) >>> del a[0] Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> TypeError: 'tuple' object doesn't support item deletion
section.para: Above you can see python is giving error when we are trying to delete a value in the tuple.
To create a tuple which contains only one value you have to type a trailing comma.
section.programlisting: >>> a = (123) >>> a 123 >>> type(a) <type 'int'> >>> a = (123, ) #Look at the trailing comma >>> a (123,) >>> type(a) <type 'tuple'>
section.para: Using the buitin function type() you can know the data type of any variable. Remember the len() function we used to find the length of any sequence ?

section.title: Sets
section.para: Sets are another type of data structure with no duplicate items. We can also mathematical set operations on sets.
And some examples of the set operations
section.programlisting: >>> a = set('abracadabra') >>> b = set('alacazam') >>> a # unique letters in a set(['a', 'r', 'b', 'c', 'd']) >>> a - b # letters in a but not in b set(['r', 'd', 'b']) >>> a | b # letters in either a or b set(['a', 'c', 'r', 'd', 'b', 'm', 'z', 'l']) >>> a & b # letters in both a and b set(['a', 'c']) >>> a ^ b # letters in a or b but not both set(['r', 'd', 'b', 'm', 'z', 'l'])

section.title: Dictionaries
section.para: Dictionaries are unordered set of key: value pairs where keys are unique. We declare dictionaries using {} braces. We use dictionaries to store data for any particular key and then retrieve them.
We can add more data to it by simply
To delete any particular key:value pair
To check if any key is there in the dictionary or not you can use in keyword.
You must remember that no mutable object can be a key, that means you can not use a list as a key.
dict() can create dictionaries from tuples of key,value pair.
If you want to loop through a dict use iteritems() method.
section.programlisting: >>> data {'Kushal': 'Fedora', 'Jace': 'Mac', 'kart_': 'Debian', 'parthan': 'Ubuntu'} >>> for x, y in data.iteritems(): ... print "%s uses %s" % (x, y) ... Kushal uses Fedora Jace uses Mac kart_ uses Debian parthan uses Ubuntu
section.para: When we try to get value for a key which does not exists we get KeyError. We can use dict.get(key, default) to get a default value when they key does not exists before.
section.programlisting: >>> data['foo'] Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in KeyError: 'foo' >>> data.get('foo', 0) 0
section.para: If you want to loop through a list (or any sequence) and get iteration number at the same time you have to use enumerate().
section.programlisting: >>> for i, j in enumerate(['a', 'b', 'c']): ... print i, j ... 0 a 1 b 2 c
section.para: You may also need to iterate through two sequences same time, for that use zip() function.
section.programlisting: >>> a = ['Pradeepto', 'Kushal'] >>> b = ['OpenSUSE', 'Fedora'] >>> for x, y in zip(a, b): ... print "%s uses %s" % (x, y) ... Pradeepto uses OpenSUSE Kushal uses Fedora

section.title: students.py
section.para: In this example , you have to take number of students as input , then ask marks for three subjects as 'Physics', 'Maths', 'History', if the total number for any student is less 120 then print he failed, or else say passed.
section.programlisting: #!/usr/bin/env python n = int(raw_input("Enter the number of students:")) data = {} # here we will store the data languages = ('Physics', 'Maths', 'History') #all languages for i in range(0, n): #for the n number of students name = raw_input('Enter the name of the student %d: ' % (i + 1)) #Get the name of the student marks = [] for x in languages: marks.append(int(raw_input('Enter marks of %s: ' % x))) #Get the marks for languages data[name] = marks for x, y in data.iteritems(): total = sum(y) print "%s 's total marks %d" % (x, total) if total < 120: print "%s failed :(" % x else: print "%s passed :)" % y
section.para: The output
section.programlisting: [kd@kdlappy book]$ ./students.py Enter the number of students:2 Enter the name of the student 1: Babai Enter marks of Physics: 12 Enter marks of Maths: 45 Enter marks of History: 40 Enter the name of the student 2: Tesla Enter marks of Physics: 99 Enter marks of Maths: 98 Enter marks of History: 99 Babai 's total marks 97 Babai failed :( Tesla 's total marks 296 Tesla passed :)
